title: Jon Pardi Is '112 Days Sober' After He 'Retired' From Alcohol
text:
Jon Pardi Reveals He's '112 Days Sober' After He 'Retired' from Alcohol: 'I Was So Unhappy with Myself' The country star said he's "lost a bunch of weight" since giving up alcohol
By Vanessa Etienne Vanessa Etienne Vanessa Etienne is an Emerging Content Writer-Reporter for PEOPLE.
People Editorial Guidelines Updated on December 28, 2023 05:10PM EST Jon Pardi. Photo: Christopher Polk/Variety via Getty Jon Pardi is entering 2024 making strides in his newfound sobriety journey.
The "Ain't Always the Cowboy" singer, 38, appeared on Amazon Music's Country Heat Weekly podcast and revealed that he’s nearly four months sober, and has lost some weight because of the lifestyle change.
"I've been 112 days sober. I’ve lost a bunch of weight," the country star told hosts Kelly Sutton and Amber Anderson. "I was pre-diabetic, and I was just like, 'I gotta stop.'"
Pardi explained that his weight ultimately left him feeling "unhappy" and drove him to make the decision.
"I was really getting to the point where every picture, every video I was so unhappy with myself," he admitted. "And where I was going, I needed to just take a break."

Jon Pardi. Jason Davis/Getty Ashley McBryde Makes Dramatic Life Changes: 'I Just Needed to Stop Killing Myself' (Exclusive) The results of his sobriety journey have even made Pardi more confident, telling others that going alcohol-free is the key to weight loss.
"I just did a photo shoot and I was like ... 'Damn, I look good,' Take that Tito's!" he said with a laugh. "But for anybody that's thinking about it, if they want to lose weight and you do drink, let me tell you, it does help tremendously if you stop."
The "Last Night Lonely" singer then teased on the show that although he gave up alcohol, his sweet tooth is still his weakness.
"I love me some ice cream," he quipped. "I'm like, 'Well, I'm not drinking. I better get this Twix candy ice cream.’ Coffee ice cream. So good."
Although Pardi didn’t give anymore insight on his sobriety journey, he noted that he’s not sure if he’ll stay committed to it.
"I'm retired, OK? Doesn't mean I can't come out of retirement," he said. "But for right now, it's been great."
